title: Global E-waste Management Market to grow at 12.82% through 2023-28 to be valued at USD 122.48 Billion: Bonafide ... - GlobeNewswire
summary: The article discusses the rapid expansion of the e-waste management market due to the increasing amount of electronic waste generated globally. It highlights the environmental and health risks associated with improper e-waste disposal and the opportunities for companies in the recycling industry.

title: Waste Expo Australia 2023: Advancing towards sustainable resource recovery - Waste Management Review
summary: Waste Expo Australia 2023 is a platform for waste management professionals to exchange ideas and showcase innovative products and solutions. The event aims to advance sustainable resource recovery management practices through discussions, exhibitions, and educational sessions.
green_innovation: TRUE. The Waste Expo Australia 2023 event contributes to environmental sustainability goals by promoting waste management practices that aim to reduce waste and carbon emissions.
business_innovation: TRUE. Waste Expo Australia 2023 introduces new products and services in the waste management industry, differing significantly from previous offerings, making it an example of business innovation.
green_product: TRUE. The event will showcase cutting-edge products and services that promote sustainable resource management, recycling, composting, and waste reduction, aligning with the principles of green products.
green_process: TRUE. Waste Expo Australia 2023 will explore methods and techniques to minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability in waste management processes, fitting the definition of green processes.

title: ElecSome brings PV upcycling to Victoria - Waste Management Review
summary: A new PV upcycling facility in Victoria transforms solar panel waste into new products, such as SolarCrete concrete. The facility aims to address the environmental challenge of end-of-life solar modules by using recycled materials.
green_innovation: TRUE. This initiative is a green innovation as it addresses the environmental challenge of solar panel waste and contributes to sustainability goals by upcycling PV modules into new products.
business_innovation: FALSE. The article does not focus on introducing new products or business processes that significantly differ from the firm's previous offerings, but rather on addressing an environmental challenge.
green_product: TRUE. The article discusses SolarCrete concrete, which is made from glass fines sourced from solar panels and promotes sustainability by conserving raw materials and reducing the carbon footprint of concrete production.
green_process: TRUE. The article highlights a green process through the PV upcycling facility, which minimizes environmental impacts by transforming solar panel waste into new products and promoting sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 562920 - Materials Recovery Facilities, 238110 - Poured Concrete Foundation and Structure Contractors, 327320 - Ready-Mix Concrete Manufacturing, 221119 - Other Electric Power Generation
greenwashing: FALSE. The article does not exhibit greenwashing as it focuses on genuine efforts to address the environmental challenge of solar panel waste and promotes sustainability through upcycling and green processes.

title: Operators appointed for Vic container deposit scheme - Government News
summary: Victoria announces a drink container recycling program with network operators for 10-cent refunds per container, split between beverages industry and independent operators.
green_innovation: TRUE. This initiative contributes to environmental sustainability goals by promoting recycling, reducing litter, and diverting waste away from landfills.
business_innovation: FALSE. The article discusses a recycling program rather than a new or significantly improved product or business process.
green_product: FALSE. The article focuses on a recycling program and network operations rather than a specific product designed to reduce environmental impact throughout its lifecycle.
green_process: TRUE. The article mentions green processes such as the recycling of plastics, processing of glass for reuse, and the responsible handling of aluminum.
